title: 104_s598
content:
The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" raises taxes on cigars and cigarettes. For cigars, the tax rate is increased to $5.8125 per thousand, and for large cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, the tax is 65.875% of the selling price but not exceeding $155 per thousand. For cigarettes, the tax rate is raised to $62 per thousand. The tax rates on cigarettes, cigarette papers, cigarette tubes, and snuff are increased as per the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995". The new tax rates are $62 per thousand for cigarettes, 3.875 cents for cigarette papers, 7.75 cents for cigarette tubes, and 36 cents for snuff. The Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995 amended tax rates on smokeless tobacco products such as snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. The new rates are $1.86 for snuff, 62 cents for chewing tobacco, and $3.4875 for pipe tobacco, effective for products removed after December 31, 1995. The Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995 amended tax rates on various tobacco products, including cigars, cigarettes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. The amendments apply to products removed after December 31, 1995. Additionally, the Act imposed a tax of $1.86 per pound on roll-your-own tobacco manufactured or imported into the United States. The definition of "roll-your-own tobacco" is clarified as tobacco suitable for making cigarettes. Amendments include adding roll-your-own tobacco to the definition of tobacco products and making technical changes to the tax code. The definition of "roll-your-own tobacco" is clarified as tobacco suitable for making cigarettes. Amendments include adding roll-your-own tobacco to the definition of tobacco products for personal consumption. The table of chapters for subtitle E of the Code is amended by replacing the item relating to chapter 52 with a new item. Chapter 52 discusses tobacco products, cigarette papers, and tubes. The effective date for the amendments made in this subsection is after December 31, 1995. A transitional rule allows individuals engaged in the tobacco business before January 1, 1996, to continue pending final action on their application. (c) Floor Stocks.--
On cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco manufactured in or imported into the United States before January 1, 1996, and held for sale, taxes are imposed. For small cigars weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand, the tax is $4.6875 per thousand. Taxes are imposed on tobacco products in the United States based on weight and type. Small cigars are taxed at $4.6875 per thousand for those weighing not more than 3 pounds, while large cigars are taxed at 53.125% of the selling price, not exceeding $125 per thousand. Small cigarettes are taxed at $50 per thousand, and large cigarettes at $105 per thousand, with exceptions for length. Cigarette papers are taxed at 3.125 cents for each 50 papers, with exceptions for length. Cigarette tubes are taxed at 6.25 cents for each 50 tubes, also with exceptions for length. On snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco, specific tax rates per pound apply, with proportional taxes on fractional parts. Liability for tax on various tobacco products held on January 1, 1996, is outlined. Liability for tax on tobacco products held on January 1, 1996, is outlined, with specific tax rates per pound and proportional taxes on fractional parts. Payment is due on February 15, 1996, following the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax on tobacco products, including cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco, was removed on January 1, 1996. Retail stocks of these products held on that date are exempt from the tax. Foreign trade zones are also exempt from these tax regulations. On January 1, 1996, tobacco products in retail stocks are exempt from taxes. Foreign trade zones are also exempt from these regulations. Tobacco products entering the US from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1996, are subject to taxes. These products are treated as being held for sale on January 1, 1996. A trust fund is established under Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code. Tobacco products like cigars, cigarettes, snuff, and pipe tobacco are treated as held for sale on January 1, 1996. A trust fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code for these products. A trust fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code for tobacco products like cigars, cigarettes, snuff, and pipe tobacco. SEC. 9512 pertains to the Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund is created in the Treasury, funded by 3% of revenue increases from tobacco-related amendments. The fund supports farmers transitioning from tobacco to other crops and provides grants to communities and individuals. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, funded by 3% of tobacco-related revenue increases, assists farmers in transitioning from tobacco to other crops and provides grants for economic diversification plans. This includes government purchase of tobacco allotments to support farmers and communities seeking alternatives to tobacco production. Sec. 9512.
